lead: There are many iconic American landscapes, but perhaps none is more evocative than the mountains and lakes of the Adirondacks. The northern forests, a mix of conifers and hardwoods, are everything we think a forest should be. The peaks are ancient, bare granite; the streams are magical, tumbling past banks blanketed in green moss and ferns. James Fenimore Cooper's Hawkeye could still be lurking in the morning mists, or at least the movie image of Daniel Day Lewis in ''The Last of the Mohicans.''
headline: Alone in the Wilds, Where Nature Makes Waves
author: By Jerry Beilinson

lead: CNN has a correspondent and crew in place, just in case news breaks out in the woods. The other networks are following along as well, betting on the proposition that President Clinton, even while on vacation, will not be able to resist a camera and boom mike in his face.
headline: Clinton Maintains a Low Profile On His Adirondacks' Vacation
author: By Marc Lacey

lead: For those without moral qualms, it has to be one of the last remaining bargains in New York State: Chop down a tree worth hundreds, even thousands, of dollars and -- if caught -- pay a paltry $10 fine.
headline: As Timber Prices Rise, So Do Thefts of Trees
author: By Winnie Hu

lead: A landmark air pollution law enacted a decade ago to reduce acid rain has failed to slow the acidification of lakes and streams in the Adirondacks, many of which are rapidly losing the ability to sustain life, according to a new federal report.
headline: Acid Rain Law Found to Fail in Adirondacks
author: By James Dao

lead: Six back-country skiers who ventured into a dangerous snowslide area were caught in a roaring avalanche and swept hundreds of yards down a mountainside in the Adirondack High Peaks of northern New York State on Saturday. Rescuers found one dead under the snow and his companions all injured, one critically.
headline: Rare Avalanche Kills One On an Adirondack Slope
author: By Robert D. McFadden

lead: When Congress enacted amendments to the Clean Air Act in 1990, environmentalists hailed them as powerful weapons in the fight to reduce acid rain. But a new federal report showed that many lakes, ponds and streams in the Northeast, particularly in the Adirondack Mountains, are continuing to turn acidic and are in growing danger of becoming lifeless.
headline: March 26-April 1; Failure Is Reported For Clean Air Act
author: By James Dao

lead: The Renco Group, a New York-based company whose holdings include a Utah company that was identified by federal environmental officials as the No. 1 toxic chemical dumper in the nation in 1998, donated $100,000 to the soft-money campaign committee set up to help Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, according to federal records.
headline: Owner of Chemical Dumper Gave to Mayor
author: By Adam Nagourney

lead: Travelers in the New York area can take their pick of transportation to view the autumn landscape along the Hudson River.
headline: By Water or by Land, Foliage on the Hudson
author: NA

lead: Some Adirondacks getaway! Hillary Rodham Clinton barely had enough time to unpack her bags at the lakeside home where the first family is spending the weekend before she was off to a political rally to talk up her Senate bid.
headline: Mrs. Clinton Takes a Busman's Holiday
author: By Marc Lacey

lead: Hillary Rodham Clinton called on Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani today to reject the nomination of the Independence Party if the organization nominates Patrick J. Buchanan to run for president.
headline: Mrs. Clinton Calls On Giuliani To Reject Independence Party
author: By Julian E. Barnes

lead: ABOUT two years ago, hundreds of alewives and striped bass, 17 small blue crabs and one 3 1/2-inch killifish with iridescent blue bands were spotted on the Hudson River near Kowawese state park in New Windsor, N.Y. This minute natural occurrence, like thousands of other such small events, was in itself far from earth shattering. But taken in context, it is a tiny piece of the sprawling mosaic that is life in and around the river.
headline: An Almanac Documents Life on the Hudson River
author: By Lynne Ames

lead: TO one who thought he had put plague-ridden Long Island behind him this summer in favor of the healthy, rugged outdoors of New York's mountains, it was more than a bit sobering to learn that the West Nile virus has been discovered upstate.
headline: OPINION; Playing the West Nile Blame Game
author: By Barry Edelson

lead: Sara Skidmore Krause, a medical student, and Dr. Souheil James Inati, a physicist, were married yesterday at the United Congregational Church in Little Compton, R.I. The Rev. Richard Manzelmann, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.
headline: Sara Krause, Souheil Inati
author: NA

lead: Stephanie King Canter and Seth Jeremiah Copeland were married yesterday by Judge Kevin J. Murphy of California State Superior Court at the Elizabeth Gamble Gardens in Palo Alto.
headline: Stephanie Canter, Seth Copeland
author: NA

lead: FIFTY-EIGHT works of art, wrapped in brown cardboard, stood lined up on the floor against the freshly painted, unadorned walls in the galleries at the Katonah Museum of Art here. The works had traveled from their homes -- in museums, with artists and in private collections -- in climate-controlled trucks.
headline: Displaying Art to Seduce Viewers
author: By Cynthia Magriel Wetzler

lead: It is usually a dream destination for avid cross-country skiers. In this shockingly mild winter, however, a long-awaited New Year's vacation at the Lapland Lake Cross-Country Ski and Vacation Center revealed more brown ground than winter wonderland. Surprisingly, however, the visit also turned into more of a jolly sleepwalk than a snowless nightmare.
headline: Snowless Trails Provide Jolly Time
author: By Jack Bell

lead: After a three-year renovation, Hillwood Museum and Gardens in Washington -- the home of the Postum Cereal Company heiress, Marjorie Merriweather Post (1887-1973) -- will reopen on Tuesday.
headline: Marjorie Post's Estate Reopens in Washington
author: By Megan Fulweiler

lead: GUIDEBOOK
headline: TRAVEL ADVISORY
author: By Joseph Siano

lead: A 78-year-old Staten Island man has the unlucky distinction of having the nation's first known case of West Nile encephalitis this year, health officials said today. Meanwhile, birds found dead from the disease from the Atlantic almost to Lake Erie led the state health commissioner to declare the first statewide outbreak of the virus.
headline: Year's First Human Case of West Nile Is Found as Outbreak Widens
author: By Richard Perez-Pena

lead: The first national accounting of toxic chemical emissions by electric power plants and the mining industry has tripled the estimated volume of those releases.
headline: Estimate of Toxic Chemical Emissions Is Tripled
author: By Winnie Hu

lead: EVEN for seasoned tree experts like Lou Sebesta, an urban forester who has seen many champions, the 125-year-old flowering dogwood in Carmel is a wonder.
headline: A Tree, a Record: Will They Last?
author: By Elsa Brenner

lead: The New York State Legislature today completed passage of a bill that seeks to reduce the amount of air pollution that drifts into New York from coal-burning power plants in Midwestern and Southern states.
headline: Albany Battles Acid Rain Fed By Other States
author: By Raymond Hernandez

lead: A state health report issued yesterday shows that rising levels of mercury have contaminated the fish in at least six more upstate water bodies, including two major reservoirs in the Catskills that supply drinking water to New York City.
headline: Mercury Levels Found Unsafe in Fish From 6 New Sites Upstate
author: By Winnie Hu

lead: Is it something in the water?
headline: Ex-Governor of Massachusetts, Back in New York, Talks of a 2nd Statehouse
author: By Adam Nagourney

lead: THE Hudson River Museum sits amid green fields and river views, in a setting as gracious as the Victorian mansion from which it sprung. Until now, however, the river was merely a timeless backdrop, or the subject of paintings that hung on the museum's walls.
headline: Making the Hudson Live Inside a Museum
author: By Roberta Hershenson

lead: They called it Horse Haven when racing was inaugurated at Saratoga Springs in 1863 for a meet that lasted three days. But the next year, the ''new'' Saratoga Race Course opened on Union Avenue. And on Wednesday, for the 132nd year, it will open for racing again, starting a prestigious six-week schedule that will feature 35 stakes races carrying purses of $8.7 million along with historic reminders that the stately old track has also grown to become ''the Graveyard of Champions.''
headline: 2-Year-Old Fillies to Go First at Saratoga
author: By Joseph Durso

lead: BATTERY PARK
headline: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
author: By Allison Fass and Liz Murray

lead: Pressing ahead with landmark litigation to curb pollutants that contribute to acid rain in the Northeast, state and federal officials said last night that they had reached a tentative settlement with a third utility to cut emissions from power plants significantly.
headline: Tentative Deal on Acid Rain Is Reached With Third Utility
author: By Randal C. Archibold

lead: IF you have lived in country far enough north to experience real seasons, you know that late autumn is when cold fronts barge in from Canada, blue smoke plumes from farmhouse chimneys, and terrified 600-pound deer leap out of hedgerows and onto the hood of your car. By the staccato crack of gunfire you will know it's hunting season.
headline: Ideas & Trends: Deerslayer; America's Embattled Autumn Blood Sport
author: By Guy Trebay

lead: Entering one of the hottest environmental debates in the state, the administration of Gov. George E. Pataki has for the first time called for the dredging of the Hudson River to remove potentially harmful PCB's.
headline: Pataki Administration Calls for Dredging of the Hudson River to Clean Up PCB's
author: By Raymond Hernandez

lead: Echoing recent warnings from the computer makers that are its most prominent customers, Microsoft said yesterday that earnings and revenue in the current quarter would be lower than previously projected because of weakening economic conditions.
headline: Microsoft Cuts Its Projections For 4th Quarter
author: By Barnaby J. Feder

lead: IN 1997 Helene Grimaud, a pianist, and J. Henry Fair, a photographer, bought a six-acre parcel off Route 35 here with a plan: to create a natural habitat for wolves while promoting wolf conservation through education.
headline: Trying to Gain Favor For a Feared Species
author: By Saxon Henry

lead: Before they even lined up for the 87th running of the Sanford Stakes, Linda Rice was spotting D. Wayne Lukas $1,941,000 and 13 years in experience. The colt she trains, City Zip, was purchased for $9,000 last year as a yearling. His colt, Yonaguska, was picked up for $1.9 million seven months ago as a 2-year-old. Rice had a handful of important stakes races on her resume; he had 13 Triple Crown victories and 20 national champions on his.
headline: City Zip Shows He Doesn't Have Cheap Speed
author: By Joe Drape

lead: Up until Tuesday afternoon, Mark Hennig was going to scratch Gold Mover from the Schuylerville Stakes. His filly had already won all three of her races, including a gritty upset of colts at Churchill Downs, and he wondered if running a 2-year-old after just 18 days of rest was the right thing to do. Besides, he had another undefeated filly, With Ability, ready to go.
headline: Gold Mover Pinch-Hits at Saratoga Opener
author: By Joe Drape

lead: MEMO from Northern California to those seeking longevity: Forget hemp nuts. Try bug juice and lanyards. Before moving from Brooklyn, N.Y., to Piedmont, Calif., less than a year ago, it would not have occurred to me that I would soon be taking family travel advice from a clinical sexologist I met at a workout studio in Berkeley. I surely never imagined that the following summer, along with my family, I would be sitting in a dining hall packed with fellow professionals and their families singing: Bruce! Bruce! Strong and able. Get your elbows off the table!
headline: All Together Now: Follow Me to Camp Tuolumne! (It Rhymes)
author: By Patricia Leigh Brown

lead: Behind the privet hedges that shield the many monstrous mansions in this village by the sea, something semi-revolutionary is brewing.
headline: Summer Residents Want Year-Round Voice
author: By Blaine Harden

lead: When we heard that the New York City Department of Parks had published ''Great Trees of New York City,'' a guide to the city's most impressive trees, we were intrigued. Although New York has no hulking redwoods, we had heard for years about a monster tree in Queens that was said to be the biggest in all five boroughs. According to the tree grapevine, this behemoth is a tulip tree (Liriodendron tulipifera) growing in an obscure corner of Alley Pond Park, a 635-acre swath of green in northeast Queens that stretches from Union Turnpike to Little Neck Bay.
headline: A Rendezvous With 2 Giants
author: By Michael Crewdson and Margaret Mittelbach

lead: WHY, you live like a queen, don't you?'' was the comment of Queen Maude of Norway to Marjorie Merriweather Post. Mrs. Post did indeed, and she filled Hillwood, her home-museum at 4155 Linnean Avenue NW, which has just reopened, with a battalion of royal objects. Her collection of imperial Russian art from the 18th and 19th centuries is the greatest in the world outside Russia, and she had one of the leading United States collections of Sevres porcelain, much of it commissioned by Catherine the Great.
headline: The Museum-Class House That Post Toasties Built
author: By Irvin Molotsky

lead: I WANTED to photograph Rockaway. When my father announced the sale of our family bungalow there, in April of last year, I suddenly felt unhinged. Even though it was nearly a decade since I'd visited the beach house or stepped foot in the ocean town of Rockaway Beach, N.Y., I still felt a sentimental attachment, an ineffable connection, to the place that, for the first 16 years of my life, was synonymous with summer. Taking pictures there would, I had hoped, enable me to tap into these feelings and transform hazy memories into black and white images.
headline: FIRST PERSON; Farewell to a Bungalow
author: By Robert Lennon

lead: As the conversion of old manufacturing buildings to loft condominiums marches on in TriBeCa, the 16-story structure nearing completion at 95 Worth Street is breaking from that trend as one of the few new luxury rentals to be built in the neighborhood in the last decade.
headline: Residential Real Estate; New Apartments in TriBeCa, but Luxury Rentals, Not Condos
author: By Rachelle Garbarine

lead: Hideo Nomo stirred quite a fuss when he joined the Dodgers in 1995. And there was always a media sideshow around Hideki Irabu in New York. Now names like Masato Yoshii, Mac Suzuki and Kazuhiro Sasaki dot major league rosters.
headline: Far East Prospects Emerging
author: By Jim Luttrell

lead: The board of the New York League of Conservation Voters, an environmental group, is deeply divided over whom to endorse in the Senate race, because its members say both candidates have strong positions on the environment.
headline: Senate Rivals Both Praised As Promoting Conservation
author: By Dean E. Murphy

lead: FOR months and months, Jacob Bump looked at apartments, riding his bicycle to open houses all over Manhattan. He knew he wanted to spend no more than $150,000 -- but other than that he was flexible.
headline: Habitats/Madison Avenue Near 32nd Street; Buying a Studio Cheap, Then Improvising
author: By Trish Hall

lead: TWENTY years later, Ken Morrow remembered how his United States Olympic teammates jumped over the boards to celebrate Mike Eruzione's go-ahead goal against the Soviet Union, but Morrow, the bearded defenseman who would be on the Islanders' four consecutive Stanley Cup champions, stared at the scoreboard clock.
headline: Sports of The Times; When All of America Skated on Golden Pond
author: NA

lead: NEW YORK
headline: METRO BRIEFING
author: Compiled by Anthony Ramirez

lead: Icons of Dance
headline: THE GUIDE
author: By Eleanor Charles

lead: A push by labor unions to lift New York State's minimum wage to $6.75 an hour, from $5.15, has turned into one of the last major battles in this year's legislative session in Albany as small businesses lobby fiercely to block an increase.
headline: Labor Seeks Minimum State Wage of $6.75
author: By Steven Greenhouse

lead: To see New York City from the water is to see it anew, spread out serenely along the horizon in the shifting light, distorted by distance, blurred by haze, magically rearranging itself as you move in the muffled quiet toward someplace, anyplace or, better yet, no place at all.
headline: Gliding in a Floating World, Life Is but a Dream
author: By Janny Scott

lead: HIDDEN in a grove of pines on a finger of land overlooking Lake George in the foothills of the Adirondacks is a shrine to a remarkable woman. Her lovely musical name was Marcella Sembrich, and though virtually forgotten today, this Polish-born soprano was once one of the glories of the operatic stage.
headline: A Voice From the Met's First Season
author: By Constance Rosenblum

lead: For decades, environmentalists dreamed of acquiring and preserving for all time the vast, privately owned tracts of beguiling woodlands, rugged ridges, hiking trails and crystalline streams and lakes known as Sterling Forest, 40 miles northwest of New York City.
headline: 3 Acquisitions Will Complete Sterling Forest
author: By Robert D. McFadden

lead: A year and a half ago, it looked as if Lake George, a blue jewel in the green Adirondacks, had dodged a biological bullet -- the zebra mussel, an invasive European mollusk that is clogging pipes, crowding local aquatic life and turning beaches into toe-slicing shell heaps from Michigan to the Hudson River.
headline: Invasive Mussels Turn Up in Lake Thought to Be Immune
author: By Andrew C. Revkin

lead: Winter's inevitable last gasp -- keep fingers crossed -- vanquished the glories of springtime yesterday. In just 18 hours, temperatures plunged 40 degrees, rain turned to whooshing gusts of snow and much of the Northeast rapidly took on the gloomy, slushy mien of January.
headline: Nobody Was Dreaming of a White April, but It Showed Up Anyway
author: By David Barstow

lead: Representative Rick A. Lazio has attracted an unbidden guest at some of his campaign events this week: a Democratic lackey in an impressively garish Uncle Sam costume who taunts Mr. Lazio over his failure to release copies of his income tax returns.
headline: Political Memo; Stunt Keeps a Focus on Lazio's Tax Returns
author: By Clifford J. Levy

lead: NOT too long ago, hundreds of men would regularly troop down into the deep, inky reaches of Philips Mine here to collect iron ore, copper and even uranium. Today, it's all about bats.
headline: Sealing the Caves But Keeping the Bats
author: By Claudia Rowe

lead: THE price of oil is affecting travel everywhere. Surcharges of $20 on a round trip are being added to most airline tickets. Airport shuttle prices are inching up. And although a spokesman for Greyhound Lines says increases in the cost of driving improve the company's business, Greyhound has also added a fuel surcharge. Officials in the hotel industry, noting the possibility that higher prices will bring a downturn in travel, say there could be an impact there, too: inexpensive motels might lower prices.
headline: Oil Prices Rise, Air Fares Follow
author: By Betsy Wade

lead: A Virginia power company, accused of violating clean-air standards and contributing to acid rain and smog in the Northeast, has agreed to a landmark legal settlement requiring that it cut emissions from eight coal-burning plants by 70 percent.
headline: Power Plants to Cut Emissions Faulted In Northeast Smog
author: By Richard Perez-Pena

lead: WOLVES! I spotted four of them from the train window, way out on a frozen lake deep in the Labrador interior. It was spitting snow, but far to the south the sun slashed through ragged clouds, spotlighting low rumpled mountains and dark green carpets of spruce. In an eye blink the pack was gone, replaced by a winter-white ptarmigan, its wings tipped jet black, which broke from the trees and raced my passenger coach for a hundred yards before it too was left behind. Wolves and ptarmigan: typical off-the-beaten-track encounters along the route of the Quebec, North Shore and Labrador Railway (QNS&L for short) -- maybe the last true bush railroad operating in North America.
headline: A North Woods Passage
author: By Richard Wien

lead: Gov. George E. Pataki signed two major environmental initiatives into law today, including a ban on the use of a common gasoline additive that has polluted underground water supplies.
headline: Pataki Signs Two Measures Aimed at Cutting Back Pollution
author: By Raymond Hernandez

lead: Kim Masters, a 19-year-old waitress here at Alpine Pizza, grew up practically in the shadow of New Jersey's biggest ski mountain, but she has never skied.
headline: Going Upscale For Downhillers
author: By Steve Strunsky

lead: THE property is like a collection of little events,'' Barbara Jakobson said of her summer place in East Hampton, N.Y. ''It's a little compound.'' She listed the small pieces: main house, shed, summer room, tennis court, pool and, parked in a poof of wild grasses, a garden folly posing as pool house -- an old, 21-foot-long aluminum travel trailer.
headline: Trailer Poseurs: From Cabanas to Offices
author: By Barbara Flanagan

lead: ''From the ankles up,'' Gordon Hlavenka said, ''I'm a fairly normal person.''
headline: The Barefoot Seek Wiggle Room
author: By Pam Belluck

lead: The federal government is preparing to announce that the gray wolf, which was once nearly shot, trapped and poisoned out of existence in the lower 48 states, is abundant enough in a few places that it no longer uniformly needs the strict protection afforded the country's most endangered species.
headline: Rules on Gray Wolf May Soon Ease
author: By Andrew C. Revkin

lead: I HAVE some new friends. Well, not friends exactly. I wouldn't recognize them if we bumped into each other, and I don't even know their real names. But they are always there when I need them -- to play games.
headline: A Fourth for Bridge or a Cozy Chat in an All-Night Bingo Hall
author: By Hilary Appelman

lead: For young women in a culture saturated with alluring images of riches and sensuality, it is an unlikely advertising come-on. Turn your back on money and men and spend your life helping people who are sick, poor and uneducated.
headline: Sisterhood Recruits for a Next Generation
author: By Lisa W. Foderaro

lead: In mountain biking lingo, ''a yard sale'' is a crash where a rider leaves gear strewn along the trail. Midway down a winding descent on a dry, rocky trail during a mountain bike race in Maui, I tried to avoid a large rock, jammed on my front brakes and went flying over the handlebars -- a judo-style fall known as an ''endo.'' I picked myself up slowly and walked up the trail to retrieve my water bottles, energy bars and spare inner tube. I wasn't badly hurt, but my already shaky confidence took a Learjet to Tijuana.
headline: High in the Saddle for a Rousing Ride That's Bumpy, Bruising and Scary
author: By Joe Glickman

lead: Camped on the banks of the Oswegatchie River deep in the Adirondacks several years ago, Paul Rezendes, a master tracker and wilderness photographer, was awakened by a black bear bashing around his camp. Naked and armed with only a canoe paddle, he chased the bear into the night. As he drifted back to sleep, the snorting bear returned, bent on sampling the contents of the well-stocked cooler that Mr. Rezendes had stashed at the far end of his camp.
headline: Stalking the Bear (Bears Optional)
author: By Joe Glickman

lead: New York State Republicans rushed to ensure that the party could still mount a serious challenge to Hillary Rodham Clinton following Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's protracted exit from the Senate contest yesterday. They rallied around the candidacy of a little-known Long Island representative as they contemplated a race whose every dynamic was altered in the space of a single afternoon.
headline: GIULIANI QUITS RACE FOR SENATE, AND G.O.P. RALLIES AROUND LAZIO
author: By Adam Nagourney

lead: New York State Republicans rushed to ensure that the party could still mount a serious challenge to Hillary Rodham Clinton following Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's protracted exit from the Senate contest yesterday. They rallied around the candidacy of a little-known Long Island representative as they contemplated a race whose every dynamic was altered in the space of a single afternoon.
headline: GIULIANI QUITS RACE FOR SENATE, AND G.O.P. RALLIES AROUND LAZIO
author: By Adam Nagourney

lead: This is a story about a man and a bird. The man is Tom Cade, admired for his vision, ingenuity, passion and persistence, who defied naysayers and spearheaded the rescue of the bird. The bird is the peregrine falcon, admired for its power, speed, nobility and hunting prowess, which 30 years ago was perched on the brink of extinction.
headline: Once Near Death, A Comeback Bird Thrives in Cities
author: By Jane E. Brody

lead: The ghost town of the white elephants.
headline: Signs of Life in a Ghost Town; New Admirers Rebuild a Mineral-Spring Retreat
author: By Glenn Collins

lead: Rudyard Kipling, a short-time resident of Vermont, said Lake Champlain was one of the finest places in the world to view a sunset. But for decades, outdoor enthusiasts on their way to Vermont's renowned mountains passed within a few miles of the lake and never knew what they were missing. They lingered at the Burlington airport only long enough to pick up their luggage.
headline: Burlington
author: By Marian Burros

lead: DAVID SEELER is a practical man. When the landscape architect needed 25,000 tons of fill to build a ha-ha, or hidden fence, down the road from his house here, he decided to give his wife a pond for her 55th birthday.
headline: A Garden Guru Who Knows When to Stop
author: By Anne Raver

lead: Beyond providing an excuse to indulge in hot dogs and fireworks, the Fourth of July weekend can still call to mind the struggle around the event the holiday commemorates, the signing of the Declaration of Independence. So perhaps a town like Bennington, whose ambience runs from the workaday to the artsy, should count itself fortunate to have so visible a reminder of Revolutionary valor.
headline: Among Memories of Old Glory
author: By Gustav Niebuhr

lead: THERE is an American tradition, nearly a century old, of hopping into the family car and heading out into the countryside without an itinerary, without the need to be anywhere at a certain time. At the peak of this carefree style of travel, back in the early 20th century, it was called ''gypsying.'' Instead of a map, these weekend wanderers were guided by curiosity.
headline: Dallying Along the Lackawanna Trail
author: By Roger Yepsen

lead: FROM the air, Westchester bears a striking resemblance to England's Lake District, its wooded hills mottled with still ponds and shimmering lakes.
headline: Slipping Away to the Past At a Handful of Lakes Just Waiting to Be Explored
author: By Lisa W. Foderaro

lead: IT seems to me that having created the Internet, the wireless electronic pocket organizer and Oreos that turn your milk bright blue when you dunk 'em, humankind has reached its technological apogee. In so doing, we've solved our most fundamental problems: ''How can I deliver, to someone far away, an annoying online sales pitch for deeply discounted off-season Adirondack time shares?'' and ''I'm a wealthy day trader and an idiot -- what day is it?'' and ''Why is my cookie so tasty yet not at all artistically ambitious or challenging to the eye?''
headline: Saving the World, One Sexy Teen at a Time
author: By Jeff Macgregor

lead: THE market was the talk of downtown Hillsborough, Carriacou. The old building, with its rusty corrugated-iron roof sheltering a handful of hard-bargaining fruit and vegetable hawkers, had stood at the foot of the town dock for as long as anyone could remember. Now the city council wanted to tear it down and relocate the market about 100 yards down the street.
headline: In Carriacou, Parrotfish And Pastel Cottages
author: By Daisann McLane

lead: ACROSS the street from the American Museum of Natural History, Betsy Gotbaum, director of the New-York Historical Society, has been watching the construction of the dazzling, hugely trumpeted $210 million planetarium with great interest and strong emotions.
headline: What It Takes
author: By Barbara Stewart

lead: Sanford I. Weill had just completed his latest coup -- the one that vaulted him into the clear, free of any rivals or pretenders to the crown -- and he was taking the stage at Carnegie Hall, where a single microphone descended from the floodlights. It was the annual shareholders' meeting of Citigroup, which had just earned more than any company had ever earned in a single quarter, and it was Weill's show. He had built the company, ledger by ledger, through a series of deals as remarkable as any in Wall Street history. And finally, it was all his. Even the stage and the velvet-cushioned seats, which, as a trustee and chairman of Carnegie Hall, Weill had restored, were, in a manner of speaking, his.
headline: Alone At the Top
author: By Roger Lowenstein

lead: Following is a transcript of the debate Wednesday night between United States Senate candidates from New York Hillary Rodham Clinton and Rick Lazio in Buffalo, as recorded by The New York Times:
headline: Transcript of the Debate Between Mrs. Clinton and Rick Lazio
author: By
